efszbyg.Author: cryptogrip
efszbyg.Text: If it were going to affect the market it already would have. That being said, the whole thing seems very odd. A large exchange losing its access to cold storage like that is poor organization and protocol on the company's part for sure, but it also stresses the importance of not leaving your bitcoin on an exchange unless the exchange offers a guarantee to cover your losses.

efseozd.Author: AussieBitcoiner
efseozd.Text:
there are currently [23,231](https://1ml.com) LN channels open. Meanwhile in the last 24 hours there were over [340,000](https://bitinfocharts.com/bitcoin/) on-chain transactions.

so at the moment we can conclude that the opening and closing of channels isn't having a significant impact on the total number of on-chain transactions.

efu68za.Author: jimjunkdude
efu68za.Text: The reason prices go up and down is humans being human.  We don't really need something real to collapse a bubble.  Yea, go ahead and bring in some bad news, and we'll fit it into the narrative, and drop the price some more.  Even with age old, legitimate, markets that are influenced by hard data, people still don't need a good goddamn reason to send the price plunging, or soaring to the sky.  I'm not saying hard data doesn't do it's thing, it doesn't hurt to have it reflected in the price, but it isn't necessary.  You're mentioning of the nonsense, which is correct, and reflected in my opinion above, is, in itself, just more nonsense.  And that's OK.   I guess we needed to break a certain number of comments today or you needed to "hear yourself talk".  So you posted some drivel.  I responded with some drivel, in kind.  There's little else to do at this point. It's a waiting game.  The planchette will start to move above a crawl at some point, then it'll walk.  People will barely even look up when it's walking.   Then someday, it'll be off and running, and everyone will be on fire, waiting for the sprint to the mainline.  People will be shitting themselves, some happy, some sad, some living to tell the tale with neither loss, nor gain, having ventured nothing.  So the cycle goes.

efu77hz.Author: jimjunkdude
efu77hz.Text:
Yes, it makes bitcoin more scarce.  Just like e'coli makes steak more scarce.  Do you think that's a good thing? One e'coli outbreak, and yea, you've subtracted a few steaks from the steak market.  The price goes up by 1/100000th of a penny.  Congratulations don't spend it all in one place.  


But e'coli breaks out several times?  Well now're just giving fickle humans a reason to avoid steak.  It's just not worth the pain, nor the mess.  


If there are clouds in the sky, does that make sunshine more scarce?

eftjdmv.Author: medatascientist
eftjdmv.Text:
First, you don’t have to buy at the bottom to profit. In fact almost nobody buys at the bottom and profit apart from few lucky folks. Question is whether it will be worth more in the future or not. In the investment world, 7% year over year appreciation is considered good, translating to doubling in 10 years. Bitcoin is riskier so it has to justify doubling in a shorter period but it it goes above 8k in the next 5 years or so it would already be considered a great investment for many. It doesn’t have to reach to 80K.

Above is for people who just want to make money. There are lots of people who are buying bitcoin for greater purposes.

efwgasv.Author: Mccawsleftfoot
efwgasv.Text:
I don't think it's going to go that high, not any time soon. The reason is, $1m per bitcoin would mean the total value of Bitcoin in circulation is not too far off from the entirety of the global stock market. Not realistic.

It would be worth more in total than the M0 money supply in the US.

We just aren't getting that high in two years, or even ten.
